questions.question: A 45-year-old man presents with bilateral scrotal swelling. On examination, tense clusters that feel like bunches of grapes are palpable posterior to the testis and positive transillumination seen. Which of the following is the most appropriate management option if the patient reports discomfort?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer : D) Excision of the cysts Explanation: The scenario suggests epididymal cyst. Excision of the cysts is recommended if the cysts cause discomfort, especially when they are large or symptomatic. Epididymal cyst Definition Fluid-filled sacs resulting from cystic degeneration of the epididymis Commonly found in middle-aged men Often bilaterally in the scrotum. Location & Palpation Positioned posterior to and separate from the testis. Palpable as tense clusters, resembling tiny bunches of grapes. Diagnosis Transilluminate like other cystic scrotal lesions; confirmed by ultrasound examination. Treatment Small, asymptomatic cysts may not require treatment. (Option D) Larger, symptomatic cysts can be surgically excised. Aspiration is ineffective due to the multilocular nature of the cysts. (Option A) For recurrent or multilocular cysts, partial or total epididymectomy may be necessary. (Option B) Option A: Aspiration is ineffective due to the cysts' multilocular nature. Option B: Total epididymectomy is considered only in cases of recurrent or multilocular cysts but may impact fertility. Option C: Ultrasound-guided drainage is not typically used for epididymal cysts. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery (28th Edition), Page: 1566

questions.question: A 35-year-old man presents with a painless, firm scrotal mass. Serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) levels are elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Chimney sweep cancer Explanation : Carcinoma of Scrotum/Chimney sweep cancer Risk factors Aromatic cyclic hydrocarbons, Coal products.Most common in men between 15-35 years. Clinical features Typically presents as a painless, firm mass in the scrotum. May include swelling, heaviness, or discomfort, though it is often asymptomatic initially. Growth starts as ulcers with everted edges and indurated base. Tumor Markers Elevated serum levels of alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG). Investigation of Choice Testicular biopsy Treatment Wide local excision with 2 cm margin of healthy skin. High radical Orchidectomy Chemotherapy and Radiation Therapy Epididymal cyst (Option A) : Benign fluid-filled sac in the epididymis and typically does not elevate tumor markers like AFP or hCG. It usually presents as a smooth, painless mass. Orchitis (Option B) : Inflammation of the testicle, usually caused by infection. It is typically associated with pain, swelling and does not usually cause elevated tumor markers. Hydrocele (Option D) : Presents as a fluid-filled sac around the testicle, which is typically painless and would not cause elevated tumor markers like AFP or hCG.

questions.question: For a patient with Stage I seminoma, which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

options.A: Radical Orchidectomy followed by adjuvant chemotherapy
options.B: Radical Orchidectomy followed by adjuvant radiotherapy

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Radical Orchidectomy followed by adjuvant radiotherapy Explanation: Management of Testicular tumour based on staging: High Radical Orchidectomy is the primary intervention done in all patients of all stages followed by : Seminoma Non-Seminomatous GCT Stage I Radiotherapy RPLND Stage II Chemotherapy Chemotherapy + RPLND Stage III & IV Chemotherapy + Metastasectomy Chemotherapy + RPLND + Metastasectomy Chemotherapy: Bleomycin-Etoposide-Cisplatin(BEP) regimen is commonly used. RPLND( Retroperitoneal Lymph Node Dissection) : Removal of Precaval,Retrocaval, Paracaval, Interaortacaval, Retroaortic, Paraaortic, Common iliac nodes and Gonadal vein. Staging of Testicular Tumour STAGE DESCRIPTION Stage I Tumour confined to testis(T1-T2), No lymph node involvement and no distant metastasis Stage II Tumour with regional lymph node involvement (N1-N3), but no distant metastasis (M0). Stage III Tumour with distant metastasis (M1a or M1b). Stage IV Includes any T, any N, with distant metastasis (M1b), or with extensive local invasion. Reference: Bailey & Love edition 28,pg 1572 SRB Surgery edition 6,pg 1230&1231 Management

questions.question: Match the tumor markers with their associated testicular tumor types: Tumor Markers Tumor Types 1. AFP (Alpha-fetoprotein) a. Seminoma 2. HCG (Human Chorionic Gonadotropin) b. Yolk Sac Tumor 3. LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase) c. Choriocarcinoma 4. CA-125 d. Ovarian cancer
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 1-b,2-c,3-a,4-d Explanation : Tumor marker Types of Tumor AFP (Alpha-fetoprotein) Yolk sac tumor Embryonal carcinoma Teratoma HCG (Human Chorionic Gonadotropin) Choriocarcinoma Embryonal carcinoma Mixed Germ Cell Tumor LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase) Seminoma PLAP (Placenta Like Alkaline Phosphatase) Seminoma GGT (Gamma Glutamyl Transpeptidase) Seminoma CA-125 is elevated in case of : Ovarian Cancer Breast Cancer Adenocarcinoma of cervix Endometrial adenocarcinoma Reference: Bailey & Love edition 28,pg 1571 Tumour markers Tumour marker-seminoma

questions.question: A 25 years old man presents with a painless testicular mass. On examination, non-tender 3 cm mass in the right testicle is found.Ultrasound reveals a homogeneous, hypoechoic intratesticular mass. Serum tumor markers show elevated beta-hCG and LDH but normal AFP. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Seminoma Explanation: Seminoma Feature Details Tumor Type Seminoma, the most common pure testicular germ cell tumor in men aged 25-45 Origin Germinal epithelium of the seminiferous tubules Clinical Features Painless, firm swelling or mass in the testicle, typically unilateral. Accounts for 50% of all testicular germ cell tumors. 10% have secondary hydrocele, 5% have gynecomastia Diagnostic Markers AFP: Normal hCG: Normal or mildly elevated LDH: Elevated Investigation Ultrasound: Homogeneous, hypoechoic mass Histology: Sheets of oval cells with clear cytoplasm, large nuclei with prominent acidophilic nucleoli FNAC: Contraindicated due to risk of tumor cell seeding and lymph node metastasis Treatment Primary: High Inguinal Radical Orchidectomy Adjuvant: Radiation therapy or chemotherapy for positive lymph nodes Leydig cell tumor (Option A) : Benign testicular tumor that typically occurs in adults aged 30-60. While it presents as a painless testicular mass, Leydig cell tumors don't typically elevate beta-hCG. Embryonal carcinoma (Option B) : Aggressive germ cell tumor that often occurs in young men. However, it typically presents with both elevated AFP and beta-hCG, not just beta-hCG alone. It's also usually more heterogeneous on ultrasound. Teratoma (Option D) :Occur in young men, they typically have normal tumor markers (both beta-hCG and AFP). On ultrasound, they usually appear heterogeneous with cystic and solid components.

questions.question: A 28-year-old man undergoes a radical orchiectomy for a painless,enlarging testicular mass. Histopathology reveals neoplastic cells confined to the seminiferous tubules without stromal invasion.Serum tumor markers are within normal limits.Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer:D) Intratubular germ cell neoplasm (ITGCN) Explanation: Intratubular Germ Cell Neoplasm (ITGCN): Precursor to invasive germ cell tumors except Teratoma, Yolk sac tumor, Spermatocytic seminoma Histology: Neoplastic germ cells are large, with clear cytoplasm and prominent nucleoli, confined within the seminiferous tubules. Risk of Progression: ITGCN has a high risk of progressing to invasive germ cell tumors, such as seminomas or non-seminomatous germ cell tumors. Clinical features: Serum tumor markers within normal limits(AFP,hCG and LDH), Affected testis is atrophied. Diagnosis: Gold standard investigation is Testicular biopsy. Treatment: Include close surveillance, radiation therapy to the contralateral testis and prophylactic orchidectomy. Seminoma (Option A): Invasive germ cell tumor with characteristic cells in sheets and lymphocytic stroma. Not confined to seminiferous tubules, unlike ITGCN. Yolk Sac Tumor (Option B): An invasive germ cell tumor often found in children, associated with elevated AFP. Histology shows Schiller-Duval bodies. Not confined to seminiferous tubules. Leydig Cell Tumor (Option C): A rare non-germ cell tumor arising from interstitial cells, often hormonally active. Not a germ cell neoplasm and not confined to seminiferous tubules.

questions.question: Match the following WHO classification of tumors with its corresponding tumor :- 1. Germ cell tumors derived from germ cell neoplasia in situ A. Gonadoblastoma 2. Germ cell tumors unrelated to germ cell neoplasia in situ B. Prepubertal-type teratoma 3. Sex cord-stromal tumors C. Sertoli cell tumor 4.Nonseminomatous germ cell tumors D. Choriocarcinoma
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 1 - A; 2 - B; 3 - C; 4 - D Explanation: World Health Organization (WHO) classification of testicular tumors Germ cell tumors derived from germ cell neoplasia in situ Noninvasive germ cell neoplasia GCNIS (germ cell neoplasia in situ) Specific forms of intratubular germ cell neoplasia Gonadoblastoma The germinoma family of tumors Seminoma Nonseminomatous germ cell tumors Embryonal carcinoma Yolk sac tumor, postpubertal type Choriocarcinoma Placental site trophoblastic tumor Epithelioid trophoblastic tumor Teratoma, postpubertal type Teratoma with somatic-type malignancy Mixed germ cell tumors of the testis Mixed germ cell tumors Germ cell tumors of unknown type Regressed germ cell tumors Germ cell tumors unrelated to germ cell neoplasia in situ Spermatocytic tumor Teratoma, prepubertal-type Yolk sac tumor, prepubertal type Testicular neuroendocrine tumor, prepubertal type Mixed teratoma and yolk sac tumor, prepubertal type Sex cord-stromal tumors of the testis Leydig cell tumor Leydig cell tumor Sertoli cell tumor Sertoli cell tumor Large cell calcifying Sertoli cell tumor Granulosa cell tumor Adult granulosa cell tumor Juvenile granulosa cell tumor The fibroma thecoma family of tumors Tumors in the fibroma thecoma group Mixed and other sex cord-stromal tumors Mixed sex cord-stromal tumor Signet ring stromal tumor Myoid gonadal stromal tumor Sex cord-stromal tumor NOS (not otherwise specified) Reference: WHO classification Testicular Tumor

questions.question: A 30-year-old male presents with a painless testicular mass. On physical examination, a solid intratesticular mass is palpable, and there is difficulty in palpating the epididymis. Which of the following associated findings would most likely be present in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Gynecomastia Explanation: Gynecomastia is seen in approximately 5% of testicular tumor cases, mainly in non-seminomatous germ cell tumors due to hCG production. Testicular tumor- clinical features Common Presentation Initial Symptom: Painless testicular lump. Heaviness: Noted with larger tumors. Pain: Uncommon, may occur due to hemorrhage, mimicking torsion. Metastatic Disease: Rarely the first symptom. Physical Examination Solid Intratesticular Mass: Palpable. Secondary Hydrocele: May complicate examination. Epididymis: Difficult to palpate due to tumor. Gynaecomastia: Seen in ~5% of cases, mainly in non-seminomatous germ cell tumors. (Option B) Bilateral Tumors: Present at diagnosis in 1-2% of cases. Presentation of Metastatic Disease (10%) Neck Mass: Supraclavicular lymph node metastasis. Cough/Dyspnea: Pulmonary metastasis. (Option A) Gastrointestinal Symptoms: Anorexia, nausea, vomiting, or hemorrhage from retroduodenal metastasis. Lumbar Back Pain: Retroperitoneal disease involving psoas muscle or nerve roots. (Option D) Bone Pain: Indicative of skeletal metastasis. Neurological Symptoms: CNS or peripheral nerve involvement. Lower Extremity Swelling: Due to iliac or caval venous obstruction or thrombosis. (Option C) Systemic Endocrine Manifestations Gynecomastia: Linked to hCG, mainly in choriocarcinoma or trophoblastic cells. Paraneoplastic Hyperthyroidism: Due to hCG's thyroid-stimulating activity. Paraneoplastic Limbic Encephalitis: Rare, associated with anti-Ma2 antibodies. Precocious Puberty: Associated with Leydig cell tumors. Option A: Cough and dyspnea are related to pulmonary metastasis, which is less common in initial presentations. Option C : Lower extremity swelling is associated with venous obstruction or thrombosis due to metastatic disease. Option D: Lumbar back pain suggests retroperitoneal metastasis, typically seen in more advanced stages. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery (28th Edition), Page: 1571 Uptodate- Clinical features-testicular tumors

questions.question: A 28-year-old man presents for a routine physical exam. He has a history of cryptorchidism corrected by orchidopexy in childhood. What is his relative risk of developing testicular cancer compared to the general population?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer : D) 3.7 to 7.5 times higher Explanation: Cryptorchidism increases the risk of developing testicular cancer by 3.7 to 7.5 times, even after surgical correction. Testicular tumor- risk factors Major Risk Factors Cryptorchidism: Most significant risk factor, increasing risk by 3.7 to 7.5 times, even after surgical correction (orchidopexy). (Option D) Family History: 3.1-fold increased risk for first-degree relatives, 6.3-fold for brothers. Male Factor Infertility: Includes conditions like Klinefelter syndrome. Personal History: Previous contralateral tumor or germ cell neoplasia in situ (GCNIS). Maternal and Perinatal Factors: Low birth weight, perinatal inguinal hernia, maternal age at conception, and exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES) during pregnancy. Additional Risk Factors Age: Most common in men aged 20–35; smaller peak after age 80. Ethnicity: Highest incidence in Caucasian men, followed by Hispanics, Asians, and African-Americans.. Age at Puberty: Early puberty may increase risk; late puberty may be protective. Genetic Conditions: Increased risk associated with Klinefelter syndrome and Down syndrome. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC10145700/ Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery (28th Edition), Page: 1569

questions.question: A 60-year-old male with a history of diabetes presents with intense pain, swelling, and erythema of the scrotum. Physical examination reveals dusky skin and subcutaneous crepitation. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Immediate surgical debridement Explanation: The scenario suggests Fournier's Gangrene. Immediate surgical debridement is crucial for removing necrotic tissue and controlling the infection. Fournier's Gangrene Definition Necrotizing infection of the soft tissues in the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region, akin to necrotizing fasciitis. Clinical Presentation Symptoms: Intense pain in the genitalia, progressing through five phases: Prodromal Phase: Fever and lethargy. Early Pain Phase: Intense pain, possible edema, pruritus. Progressive Phase: Increased pain, erythema. Crepitation Phase: Dusky skin with subcutaneous crepitation. Gangrene Phase: Gangrene with purulent discharge. Pain may decrease as gangrene progresses. Severity ranges from localized tenderness to septic shock. Risk Factors Peripheral vascular disease, diabetes mellitus, malnutrition, alcoholism, immunocompromised states. Diagnosis Clinical presentation supported by imaging or lab findings. Management Initial Treatment: 1. Fluid resuscitation. 2. Broad-spectrum antibiotics. 3. Surgical debridement of necrotic tissue. Additional Measures: 1. Urinary and fecal diversion to prevent wound contamination. 2. Intensive monitoring for sepsis. 3. Wound review and vacuum-assisted dressing. 4. Skin grafting post-infection control. Option A: Oral antibiotics alone are insufficient for such a severe infection. Option C: Observation without intervention would allow the infection to progress rapidly. Option D: Aspiration is not effective in managing necrotizing infections. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery (28th Edition), Page: 1573-1574 Sabiston 21st edition, page: 1372

questions.question: Which of the following factors are responsible for testicular descent? Testosterone Gubernaculum Intra-abdominal Pressure CGRP (Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide) INSL3 (Insulin-like 3) Processus Vaginalis
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 1,2,3,4,5,6 Explanation: Factors responsible for testicular descent: Factor Role in Testicular Descent Testosterone Stimulates gubernaculum shortening, guiding the testes into the scrotum. Gubernaculum A ligament that pulls the testes down during descent. Intra-abdominal Pressure Helps push the testes through the inguinal canal. CGRP (Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide) Supports gubernaculum development during the early transabdominal phase. INSL3 (Insulin-like 3) Promotes gubernaculum elongation, aiding descent. Processus Vaginalis Provides the pathway through which the testes descend. Basic Surgical Anatomy of the Testis Location and Structure Paired oval-shaped organs in the scrotum. Suspended by the spermatic cord (contains blood vessels, nerves, vas deferens). Layers: Tunica Vaginalis: Double-layered serous membrane from the peritoneum. Tunica Albuginea: Dense, fibrous capsule beneath the tunica vaginalis. Blood Supply Arterial Supply Venous Drainage Testicular Artery: From the abdominal aorta. Pampiniform Plexus: Drains into the testicular veins. Cremasteric Artery: From the inferior epigastric artery, supplies the cremaster muscle. Right Testicular Vein: Drains into the inferior vena cava. Artery of the Vas Deferens: From the superior vesical artery, also contributes to testicular blood supply. Left Testicular Vein: Drains into the left renal vein. Lymphatic Drainage: Para-aortic lymph nodes (L1 level) Developmental Anatomy Descent: Testes develop in the abdomen and descend via the inguinal canal. Position of Testis in Intrauterine Life Abdomen (2nd Month/7th Week) ↓ Pelvis (Iliac Fossa) (3rd Month/12th Week) ↓ Deep Inguinal Ring (End of 6th Month/24th Week) ↓ Passes Through Inguinal Canal (During 7th Month/25th-28th Week) ↓ Superficial Inguinal Ring (8th Month/29th-32nd Week) ↓ Enters Scrotum (Beginning of 9th Month/33rd Week) ↓ Base of Scrotum (Before Birth/End of 9th Month/36th Week) Cryptorchidism: Undescended testis; risks include infertility and cancer.

questions.question: A 35-year-old man presented with a swelling of the scrotum, which was diagnosed as a spermatocele. Which of the following features of the swelling would have led to this diagnosis?

options.A: Location of the swelling at the head of the epididymis, above and behind the body of the testis
options.C: Barley water-like fluid with spermatozoa on aspiration cytology

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) All of the above Explanation: All are features are suggestive of spermatocele Spermatocele: Definition A unilocular, acquired retention cyst derived from blockage of epididymis Location Head of the epididymis, above and behind the body of the testis Fluid Content Barley water-like Includes spermatozoa Characteristics Soft, cystic, and transilluminant Perceived by the patient as an additional testis Diagnosis Confirmed through aspiration cytology Treatment Can be left alone if asymptomatic Excision is performed if the spermatocele is large or symptomatic Reference: SRB 6th edition, page 1063

questions.question: A 25-year-old tall, thin male presents with a dull, aching pain in his left groin and scrotum, describing a "bag of worms" sensation on palpation. He was suggested to undergo Palomo's Operation. Which of the following describes the procedure?

options.A: Suprainguinal extraperitoneal ligation of the testicular vein

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Suprainguinal extraperitoneal ligation of the testicular vein Explanation: The scenario is that of varicocele Palomo's Operation involves suprainguinal extraperitoneal ligation of the testicular vein Varicocele : Dilatation and tortuosity of the pampiniform plexus of veins and testicular veins Common Occurrence More common in tall, thin young men More frequent on the left side, but can be bilateral Causes Idiopathic Absence or incompetent valve at the junction of the left testicular vein and left renal vein Perpendicular entry of the left testicular vein into the left renal vein Left-sided renal cell carcinoma causing blockage of the left testicular vein Effects Increased temperature in the scrotum, depressing spermatogenesis and causing infertility Symptoms Swelling at the root of the scrotum Dragging pain in the groin and scrotum "Bag of worms" feeling Impulse on coughing Swelling reduces on lying down (except in renal cell carcinoma) Investigations Venous Doppler of the scrotum and groin Ultrasound of the abdomen to check for kidney tumors Semen analysis Treatment Options Palomo's Operation: Suprainguinal extraperitoneal ligation of the testicular vein Ligation of veins Excision of veins

questions.question: Which of the following statements on hydrocele is false?

options.A: Fluid is collected between the two layers of the tunica vaginalis
options.B: Primary vaginal hydrocele is common in middle-aged men
options.C: Lord's plication is done for large hydrocele n
options.D: Congenital hydrocele is reduced on lying down

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Lord's plication is done for large hydrocele Explanation: Lord’s plication is done for small, thin hydroceles with clear fluid Hydrocele: Collection of fluid between the two layers of the tunica vaginalis of the testis Aetiology Defective absorption of fluid by tunica vaginalis due to endothelial wall damage by low-grade infection Excessive production of fluid (secondary hydrocele) Interference with drainage of fluid by lymphatic vessels of the cord Communication with the peritoneal cavity Primary Vaginal Hydrocele Common in middle-aged men, prevalent in tropical countries Testis is usually large and non-palpable Fluctuant Can get above the swelling Initially transilluminant, but becomes non-transilluminant if long-standing Infantile Hydrocele Tunica and processus vaginalis distended up to the internal ring No connection with the peritoneal cavity Congenital Hydrocele Processus vaginalis communicates with the peritoneal cavity Fluid disappears when lying down and recollects when standing Encysted Hydrocele of the Cord Fluid collection in a portion of the patent funicular process of tunica vaginalis Fluctuant and transilluminant Located in the inguinal/inguinoscrotal/scrotal part Secondary Vaginal Hydrocele Causes: Infection (filariasis, tuberculosis), injury (trauma, post herniorrhaphy), tumor (malignancy) Usually small, lax, and testis is palpable except in cases of filariasis where it can be very large Surgical Procedure Lord's plication - small, thin hydrocele with clear fluid Jaboulay's operation - partial sac removal and eversion

questions.question: A 15-year-old boy presented with a sudden onset of pain in the scrotum, groin, and lower abdomen. On examination of the scrotum, he is showing Deming’s sign. What is Deming’s sign?

options.A: The affected testis is positioned high
options.D: The affected testis is positioned low

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) The affected testis is positioned high Explanation: Given is a scenario of testicular torsion In Deming’s sign, the affected testis is positioned high due to twisting and cremaster muscle spasm Testicular torsion: An emergency condition where the testis twists on its axis, compromising blood supply, potentially leading to gangrene within 12-24 hours Direction of Rotation Right Testis: Rotates clockwise Left Testis: Rotates counterclockwise Predisposing Factors Inversion of the Testis High Investment of Tunica Vaginalis Gap Between Testis and Epididymis Heavy Straining Features Age Group: Common in children and adolescents Symptoms: Sudden onset of pain in the scrotum, groin, and lower abdomen; vomiting due to pylorospasm Signs: Tenderness, redness, and edema of the scrotal skin Deming's Sign: Affected testis is positioned high due to twisting and cremaster muscle spasm Angell's Sign: Opposite testis lies horizontally due to the presence of mesorchium Investigations WBC Count: Elevated levels Doppler Study: To assess testicular artery pulsation Ultrasound Abdomen Treatment Emergency Exploration: Scrotum exploration and untwisting of the testis. The viability of the testis is checked. Fixation: If viable, the testis is fixed to the scrotal sac with 2-3 interrupted nonabsorbable sutures (Prolene). Timing: If surgery occurs within 12-24 hours, viability may be retained. Any delay can lead to gangrene, requiring orchidectomy. Orchidectomy Consideration: If in doubt, the testis can be retained temporarily, with orchidectomy postponed to assess viability. Postoperative Care: A repeat Doppler study confirms viability. The opposite testis should also be fixed to prevent torsion. Reference: SRB 6th edition, pages 1068-1070

questions.question: A 27-year-old male is presented with a swollen, red, and painful epididymis. On examination, his vas deferens has a beaded texture and epididymis is craggy. A diagnosis of epididymo-orchitis was made. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Tuberculosis Explanation: TB epididymo-orchitis presents with a beaded vas deferens and a craggy epididymis. Epididymo-orchitis: Inflammation of testes and epididymis It can be acute or chronic Causes Viral infections like mumps Bacterial Filarial Tuberculosis Gonococcal infections Schistosomiasis Features Epididymis - pain, tenderness, swelling, thickening Hydrocele Tuberculosis: Beaded vas deferens with a craggy epididymis Treatment General: Use of analgesics and antibiotics. Specific Treatment: Diethylcarbamazine citrate (DEC) 100 mg for 3 weeks. Evaluation: Specific causes should be ruled out. Psychological Care: Long-term epididymitis can cause psychological disturbance; reassurance is necessary. Reference: SRB 6th edition, page 1075

questions.question: A 4-year-old boy has a right testis that intermittently moves between the scrotum and the groin, especially during physical activity. The testis is retractable but can be brought down into the scrotum upon gentle manipulation, while the left testis is normally positioned. What is the most likely physiological explanation for this intermittent movement of the testis?

options.D: Increased tone of the cremasteric muscle

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Increased tone of the cremasteric muscle Explanation: In this scenario, the intermittent movement of the testis between the scrotum and the groin, especially during physical activity, represents a retractile testis. Retractile testis A retractile testis is a condition where a normally descended testis moves between the scrotum and the groin due to an overactive cremasteric reflex and increased tone of the cremasteric muscle. This reflex, which is triggered by physical activity or cold temperatures, causes the cremasteric muscle to contract, pulling the testis up into the groin. In a retractile testis, the testis can be manually descended into the scrotum with gentle manipulation. Typically, no treatment is required, as the condition often resolves spontaneously by puberty.

questions.question: A 2 year old boy underwent surgery for an ectopic testis, followed by an orchidopexy. Several weeks later, he presents with symptoms including swelling and pain in the scrotum, along with fever. On examination, the scrotum is tender, and the affected testis appears to be positioned higher than normal. What is the most likely cause for these symptoms?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Testicular torsion Explanation: Testicular torsion is a possible complication after orchidopexy, especially if the fixation of the testis was not secure or if there was a delay in the procedure. The symptoms of pain, swelling, and high-riding testis are characteristic of torsion. This is a surgical emergency as it can lead to testicular ischemia and necrosis if not treated promptly. Complications of orchidopexy Infection Postoperative infection at the incision site or scrotum. Hemorrhage Bleeding or hematoma formation. Testicular Atrophy Shrinkage or loss of testicular function. Testicular Necrosis Death of testicular tissue due to inadequate blood supply. Recurrent Undescended Testicle Testicle reascends, possibly requiring reoperation. Scrotal Swelling Postoperative scrotal swelling or hydrocele formation. Infertility Rare, due to damage affecting fertility. Testicular Torsion Twisting of the testicle, risking blood supply. Injury to Adjacent Structures Potential damage to vas deferens or blood vessels. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK560904/

questions.question: An 8 months old infant is undergoing surgical exploration for an undescended testis. The surgeon follows the standard approach and examines the inguinal canal but does not find the testis in the usual tract. Which location should the surgeon check next?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Superficial inguinal pouch Explanation: According to the given scenario, the diagnosis point towards ectopic testis The testis may end up in abnormal locations such as: Superficial Inguinal Pouch (Most Common) Femoral Region(Femoral canal) Perineum: Retroperitoneum Ectopic testis An ectopic testis is when a testicle fails to descend into the scrotum and lies outside the normal descent tract typically due to abnormalities in the gubernaculum Management: Surgical Correction (Orchidopexy): To reposition the testis into the scrotum. Complications: Infertility Increased risk of testicular cancer

questions.question: All are true regarding undescended testis, except?

options.A: Seminoma is the most common tumor associated with undescended testis
options.B: Elevated abdominal temperature impairs sperm production
options.C: Orchidopexy is typically performed between 6-12 months of age.
options.D: Undescended testis causes loss of secondary sexual characteristics due to Leydig cell impairment.

questions.explanation: cell impairment. Correct Answer: D) Undescended testis results in loss of secondary sexual characteristics due to Leydig cell impairment. Explanation: Leydig cells are unaffected in cryptorchidism, maintaining secondary sexual characteristics, while Sertoli cells are impaired, affecting spermatogenesis. Undescended Testis (Cryptorchidism) Definition Cryptorchidism is a condition where one or both testes fail to descend into the scrotum from the abdomen. Locations Inguinal/Palpable undescended testis: 80% Abdominal/Non-Palpable undescended testis: 20% Causes and Associated Conditions Developmental and Genetic Factors: Conditions like Klinefelter syndrome and testosterone imbalances can impair testicular descent. Prematurity and Maternal Factors: Premature birth and maternal issues like diabetes or medication exposure can lead to undescended testes. Mechanical and Physical Factors: Obstructions in the inguinal canal, scrotum, or related conditions such as inguinal hernia can prevent normal testicular descent. Complications (SATHI Mnemonic): S: Sterility - Elevated abdominal temperature can impair sperm production, leading to potential infertility if untreated. (Option B) A: Atrophy - Prolonged exposure to heat can cause the testis to shrink or become non-functional. T: Trauma, Tumor, Torsion - Increased risk of testicular torsion, which can cause severe pain and potentially result in testicular loss. The most common tumor associated is seminoma (Option A) with the highest risk of tumor development in abdominal testes. H: Hernia - Over 90% of cases are associated with a patent processus vaginalis, increasing the risk of inguinal hernia. I: Inflammation - The undescended testis is more prone to inflammatory conditions. Note: Leydig cells are unaffected, maintaining secondary sexual characteristics, while Sertoli cells are impaired, affecting spermatogenesis. Diagnosis Palpable undescended testis: Inguinal exploration. Non-Palpable undescended testis: Diagnostic laparoscopy. Imaging: Ultrasound or MRI may be utilized to locate the testis. Treatment Surgical Repositioning (Orchidopexy): Usually performed when the child is between 6-12 months old. (Option C) Types of Orchidopexy Ombridannes Keetley-Torek Stephen-Fowler Ladd & Gross Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery (28th Edition), Page 1559 -1561. Schwartz's Principles of Surgery (11th Edition), Page 1777. SRB's Manual of Surgery (6th Edition), Page 1065 -1068.
